task.title: Task: Sorting
task.shortdesc: Sort records in ascending or descending order based on one or more fields.

taskbody.context:
You can sort the records in a table based on the values ​​in one or more fields. Sorting can be in ascending and descending order.
In the next steps you need to change the table Customers so that an overview is created of first the city, then the last name and then first name. The records must also be sorted in that order. Table Customers sort on city, last name and first name
Table Customers sort on city, last name and first name

step.stepresult: Table Customers is displayed in the Datasheet View.

step.cmd: Select the column City by clicking on the column header.
Drag the column City to the left so this will be the first column in the table.
Same way, move the columns LastName and FirstName to, respectively the 2e and 3e position in the table.
Click in column City on the arrow at the right side in the column header and select from the shortcut menu Sort A to Z.
step.stepresult: Access reorganizes the records in alphabetical order by city and shows a small upward pointing arrow () at the right side of the column header to indicate the sort order.

step.cmd: Cancel the sorting through tab Home Remove Sort (group Sort & Filter) .
Select the columns City, LastName, and FirstName.
Choose tab Home Ascending (group Sort & Filter) .
step.stepresult: Access reorganizes the records in ascending alphabetical order, first by city, then by the last name and then by the first name. At the right side of each of the headers of these three columns, you can see the small upward pointing arrow.

step.cmd: Close the table Customers and choose No on the question to save the changes.
